Effective leadership involves adapting management styles to suit the needs and experience levels of the team members. Senior and experienced team members typically value autonomy and trust in their expertise. If they feel micromanaged, it can lead to frustration and reduced productivity. By adjusting the management approach—granting them more independence while maintaining appropriate oversight—the project manager can address their concerns and foster a more collaborative and productive work environment.

By adjusting the management style (option A), the project manager demonstrates responsiveness to team feedback, respects their expertise, and builds trust within the team.
